reviewText: Margaret Thomas, a beautiful loving mother who has a disability. She has six boys. She has a really loving and close marriage with her husband. He supports her with looking after the boys and the home. Until one day, her husband gets diagnosed with a mental illness. Margaret finds herself fighting to proof she can be a mother and a wife especially when the social services try and take her children away. It's the love and strength that shines from Margaret. Jean Smart gives such an amazing performance. As well as the other actors.A beautiful movie, it really is!I strongly recommend this movie to anyone. You won't be disappointed!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was thrilled to discover this movie had finally been released on DVD. I discovered the DVD release by accident and I ordered it right away. I saw the movie on television sometime ago and loved it.  What a heart-warming film and Jean Smart was great in her portrayal of a mentally retarded (slow) mother fighting the welfare agency to keep her children when the agency thinks she isn't capable to raise them due to her condition. Do see it if you get the chance. You won't be sorry!
Title: N/A

reviewText: OMG where does one begin? The Yarn Princess is a priceless piece of work. The story is an amazing story of pain, suffering and triumph. A great family movie that will bring you to tears within the first 15 minutes and keep you in tears for a good 40 minutes. Jean Smart is powerful and so Oscar worthy in her performance of a developmentally challenged mother of 5 boys who finds herself having to prove to the state that she is fit to care for her children when her husband becomes too ill to support the family. This movie has become one of my top 10 best films and I could easily say one of the top 5. Its a little unknown masterpiece with guts and glory! A must have for all serious movie lovers!!!!!
summary: A MUST have for all Serious Movie collectors
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jean Smart is fantastic in the role of a borderline developmentally  disabled woman.  I won't give the story away, but it is a tear-jerker with a happy ending.  Watch this with your teenage daughter. It opens up an avenue for discussion on exactly what makes a "good" parent and forming relationships with the developmentally disabled.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jean Smart delivers an inspiring performance as a developmentally-challenged, but very intuitive and loving mother of six boys. The father's healh unexpectedly prevents him from supporting the family, and the boy's mother has to fight a legal battle to keep her children. I've always enjoyed Jean's performances, yet it's hard to imagine how she could portray this mother so convincingly. What talent!
